title: Do you have to list property acquired after date of separation on petition (fl-100) and declaration of assets and debts (fl-160)
question: Do you have to list property acquired after the date of separation on the petition (fl-100) and declaration of assets and debts (fl-160)?
question_tags: Divorce,Alternatives to divorce,Dissolution of marriage,Legal separation and divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Separate property in a divorce,Divorce court,Divorce by default judgment,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Divorce and family,Family law,Marital property,Default judgment
answers: Absolutely, otherwise you may be accused of hiding assets which has many consequences. You can always prove the assets are separate property, but once you fail to disclose the dynamics and financial sanctions can be detrimental.
The decision to list and consequences of listing those items should be evaluated by a local divorce attorney.

the main question is if you were legally separated or just stopped living together..
if you were not legally separated then you must list the property but I WILL REALLY suggest to hire a lawyer to advise you accordingly since issues can arise in reference to the funds you used to acquire those assets..and if you can prove the source of that funds..
